Patch Set 16:

(2 comments)

Why do we need the SubType?

Can the 'Type' be sufficient to identify the device?

No, the Type property has value of "Firmware", which includes common section "FirmwareInfo" and device/hardware section "UpdateInfo" and type of UpdateInfo is depicted by SubType.

Also, Type and Name are two must properties for elements in expose section https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/entity-manager/schemas/README.md?r=ec1137d5#63.

If the 'Type' is 'Firmware', then it's a separate exposes record?

So the firmware specific properties will be stored in a separate record from the description of the actual device?

For example, when configuring a voltage regulator which also provides sensor readings, will 2 separate records be required?

That would introduce some duplication in Bus and Address fields.

> If the 'Type' is 'Firmware', then it's a separate exposes record?

I have updated the diff and defined generic FirmwareInfo which can be used in device/firmware specific blocks.

> 
> So the firmware specific properties will be stored in a separate record from the description of the actual device?
> 
> For example, when configuring a voltage regulator which also provides sensor readings, will 2 separate records be required?
> 
> That would introduce some duplication in Bus and Address fields.

There are many existing devices that lack schema definitions, and VR is one such device. Therefore, it will be necessary to define schemas for these devices in the future, ensuring compatibility with existing users, such as dbus-sensors.

You are using 'CompatibleName' here but the other patch
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/74653 (patchset 7)

is using 'Compatible'. Is it intended or a typo.
Yes, this is intended. I would be updating https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/74653 to refer to this patch directly.

```com.<vendor>.Hardware.<XXX>```

nit: Can we reword this as a regex or refer to a place where it's defined?

It is already mentioned that it is in the phosphor-dbus-interfaces, so I don't think we need to provide a specific link here as it is an implicitly known repository internal to OpenBMC and definitions are under yaml/com.

This breaks the intent of EM.  If we can just hardcode a compatible interface, there's no need for it to be in an exposes record.  Just put it in code.

Config stanzas should be freestanding, and not have a relation to other software in OpenBMC (so that people that aren't openbmc experts can actually configure this stuff).

So if there's a description for CompatibleName that can be put here, lets put it here, and not bound in on dbus definitions.  They might match, and that's fine, but if this is an enumeration, it needs to be called out as such, and describe how folks can configure it.


As written, It could be a lot of things.

> so that people that aren't openbmc experts can actually configure this stuff

While I understand this was an original desire of EM, it doesn't seem to match reality.  Pretty much single contributor since 2022 has been someone relatively active in the community.

https://gist.github.com/williamspatrick/42361153a246bd5a11ef2aa3874a5692

> This breaks the intent of EM. If we can just hardcode a compatible interface, there's no need for it to be in an exposes record. Just put it in code.

I don't understand what you've written here.

The purpose of this record is to say "this FRU has a firmware blob that can be updated and the update image needs to be 'Compatible' in this way".  How do we "just put that in code"?  This seems to be exactly what EM configurations are for.

> So if there's a description for CompatibleName that can be put here, lets put it here, and not bound in on dbus definitions. They might match, and that's fine, but if this is an enumeration, it needs to be called out as such, and describe how folks can configure it.

Can you elaborate on what action you'd like to see here; is it just a change of the description?

There is `xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Decorator.Compatible` where the intended design is for someone to define an empty dbus interface with enumerations, which become the valid values of a possible Compatible.  You can see some existing ones here: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/3eb0180161fc42a91fd2197f60695da1541e8083/yaml/com/meta/Hardware/BMC.interface.yaml#L17

(These are already used as part of the BMC update identifiers: https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/88c1c16b4583b1b2bd890dcacaa22290b940fc82/meta-facebook/meta-yosemite4/conf/machine/yosemite4.conf#L9 )

There was a question on how this is suppose to work on Discord also, so I must have done a poor job of documenting it.  https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/867820390406422538/1317152417564987432

I don't know how we reconcile the "this needs to be simple enough that people who don't understand OpenBMC can configure it" with "we need to ensure these are unique and documented so they can be reasoned about".  I know at one point someone suggested using device-tree style naming (ie. "meta,yosemite4") but those are similarly understood only by people who understand kernel device trees.  Using reverse-DNS style is pretty widely used all over industry (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_domain_name_notation#Examples) and seems pretty straight-forward to understand to me (plus it aligns with all our dbus stuff).

We could require people to add to a big list of valid compatibles in EM so you could use the short name (ie. "Yosemite4") but that seems like extra steps for the same effect and it doesn't allow us to handle two companies ending up with the same code-name / model-name for two different products.

> > so that people that aren't openbmc experts can actually configure this stuff
> 
> While I understand this was an original desire of EM, it doesn't seem to match reality.  Pretty much single contributor since 2022 has been someone relatively active in the community.

Sure, and that's fine.  It doesn't mean they're an expert on every subsystem for which they wrote a config file for.  Point still stands.

> 
> https://gist.github.com/williamspatrick/42361153a246bd5a11ef2aa3874a5692
> 
> > This breaks the intent of EM. If we can just hardcode a compatible interface, there's no need for it to be in an exposes record. Just put it in code.
> 
> I don't understand what you've written here.

"Compatible" doesn't mean anything outside of software.  Maybe we just need to redefine this from the point of view of the users?

> 
> The purpose of this record is to say "this FRU has a firmware blob that can be updated and the update image needs to be 'Compatible' in this way".  How do we "just put that in code"?  This seems to be exactly what EM configurations are for.

Cool, so then lets put that in the definition exactly what user facing field we're referring to, (PLDM FWUPDAte header compatibility I suspect?) THen this should be fine.

> 
> > So if there's a description for CompatibleName that can be put here, lets put it here, and not bound in on dbus definitions. They might match, and that's fine, but if this is an enumeration, it needs to be called out as such, and describe how folks can configure it.
> 
> Can you elaborate on what action you'd like to see here; is it just a change of the description?


Change the description and name to match something user facing.  What does the software actually do with the information in this?  If this is to match up a PLDM header (which I think it is) lets call it PLDMHeaderCompatibleField (or something like that) and give it the appropriate description.

> 
> There is `xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Decorator.Compatible` where the intended design is for someone to define an empty dbus interface with enumerations, which become the valid values of a possible Compatible.  You can see some existing ones here: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/3eb0180161fc42a91fd2197f60695da1541e8083/yaml/com/meta/Hardware/BMC.interface.yaml#L17


Right.... those are all Meta systems, which is fine.  If this is some Internal Meta identifier, lets get it called out as such.  (I'm pretty sure IBM has a similar internal identifier).

> 
> (These are already used as part of the BMC update identifiers: https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/88c1c16b4583b1b2bd890dcacaa22290b940fc82/meta-facebook/meta-yosemite4/conf/machine/yosemite4.conf#L9 )
> 
> There was a question on how this is suppose to work on Discord also, so I must have done a poor job of documenting it.  https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/867820390406422538/1317152417564987432
> 
> I don't know how we reconcile the "this needs to be simple enough that people who don't understand OpenBMC can configure it" with "we need to ensure these are unique and documented so they can be reasoned about".  I know at one point someone suggested using device-tree style naming (ie. "meta,yosemite4") but those are similarly understood only by people who understand kernel device trees.  
> Using reverse-DNS style is pretty widely used all over industry (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_domain_name_notation#Examples) and seems pretty straight-forward to understand to me (plus it aligns with all our dbus stuff).
> 

I think the big thing here is to add an appropriate name and description of what the heck this means without using a Dbus name, dbus path, or identifier.  Once we have that, I really suspect there's something better than "CompatibleName" but I'm also not sure what this parameter does, so it's hard to make suggestions.

> We could require people to add to a big list of valid compatibles in EM so you could use the short name (ie. "Yosemite4") but that seems like extra steps for the same effect and it doesn't allow us to handle two companies ending up with the same code-name / model-name for two different products.

Agreed, just making a list doesn't seem great either.

This is a very long thread, so i am not going to reply on all the messages in this thread, but only actionable ones so we can conclude on the points being discussed -

* Property Name

> I think the big thing here is to add an appropriate name and description of what the heck this means without using a Dbus name, dbus path, or identifier. Once we have that, I really suspect there's something better than "CompatibleName" but I'm also not sure what this parameter does, so it's hard to make suggestions.

I wouldn't recommend using keyword "PLDM" in property names for firmwareInfo as its better to keep EM definitions independent of packaging format as different vendors may choose different formats. Since, this is part of FirmwareInfo definition i am suggesting the property name as "CompatibleHardware" or "CompatibleDevice" and Description as "Compatible hardware/device for the firmware". Let me know if you have any other suggestions.

* Property Value

>> There is xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Decorator.Compatible where the intended design is for someone to define an empty dbus interface with enumerations, which become the valid values of a possible Compatible. You can see some existing ones here: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/3eb0180161fc42a91fd2197f60695da1541e8083/yaml/com/meta/Hardware/BMC.interface.yaml#L17

> Right.... those are all Meta systems, which is fine. If this is some Internal Meta identifier, lets get it called out as such. (I'm pretty sure IBM has a similar internal identifier).

@Ed as @Patrick mentioned above, every vendor would need to define their Hardware compatible definitions in the PDI, for example, as Meta and IBM have done for their hardware. This is nothing specific to Meta or IBM but a general design approach to take for hardware definitions. You already seem to agree "not making a list", so if property is renamed to something better (Some suggestions above), are you fine with using these fully qualified names?
Do all systems have both of these?  I'd assume it's likely they have one or another.

This isn't about a system, but a device.  Anyhow...

The design suggests that we need both of them as a PLDM image identifier, which is the purpose of this configuration.  The reason is because we'd like to be able to differentiate (and block as necessary) two different images that work functionally on the same hardware but have not been qualified in different environments.

For an example I made up on the fly, we could have a different compatible of `com.meta.Hardware.Yosemite4.CX7` vs `com.meta.Hardware.Catalina.CX7` and ensure that the image that was qualified for Yv4 is never applied to Catalina, even thought it is the same hardware.

(What I wrote above actually doesn't work today because the CX7 would have the "Compatible" and there isn't currently a way to tweak them per-machine; we might work on that next half.  We do have concrete cases of the same CPLD being used for different purposes and so while the VendorIANA would be the same we need to have different compatible identifiers so we don't end up putting one CPLD image on a different [purpose] CPLD and brick the whole device.)
@Ed I don't see any further comments on this, so i assume you are fine with @Patrick's response?
